Shane Mingins wrote:
> 
> --- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
> 
>  >
>  > To solve the problem, testFindAll() should set up
>  > the data it needs in
>  > the database, so that it controls the expected
>  > outcome. This is an
>  > important trait of any good test, and not just tests
>  > that use a database.
> 
> I preface this question with "I know very little about
> EJB's"
> 
> Is it possible to implement the findAll logic in a
> POJO which is then easier to test?  Or is the code
> likely to be just a call to an EJB API?

It's certainly possible. Typically all one needs to do is pass in the 
DataSource or Connection to the POJO and off you go.

I have found in general, though, that when someone asks a question like 
this, it's more effective to nudge them in the right direction, rather 
than tell them they're doing it all wrong. :) For that reason, I suggest 
small, useful improvements, rather than overhauling the approach.

Sometimes the person comes back and tells me that what they have is 
better, but they want something even better than that. At that point, I 
talk about decoupling database client code from the database.
